channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Mart√≠nez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Afghan who helped U.S. military arrested by ICE after routine immigration hearing
item.description: An Afghan who helped U.S. military forces at war was arrested by ICE agents after appearing for an immigration hearing in San Diego. He may now face deportation despite death threats from the Taliban.

item.title: Democratic Rep. Adam Smith discusses U.S. policy on the Israel-Iran conflict
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep asks Rep. Adam Smith, D-Wash., top Democrat on the House Armed Services Committee, about U.S. policy on the conflict between Israel and Iran.

item.title: President Trump says he hasn't decided whether to strike Iranian nuclear facility
item.description: President Trump on Wednesday declined to say whether the United States is moving closer to a decision to strike Iranian nuclear facilities.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: President Trump says he hasn't decided whether to strike Iranian nuclear facility, the latest on the Iran-Israel conflict, Social Security benefits face big cuts in 2033 if Congress doesn't act.

item.title: KPMG chief economist Diane Swonk discusses the state of the U.S. economy
item.description: The Fed held interest rates steady on Wednesday. NPR's Steve Inskeep asks Diane Swonk, chief economist at KPMG, about the state of the U.S. economy and what it means for consumers.

item.title: Claims that seed oils are harming Americans' health are causing problems for farmers
item.description: Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others have said that seed oils are poisoning Americans. The medical community mostly rejects those claims, but they are causing problems for farmers.

item.title: Some in California farm community fear disruptions due to immigration enforcement
item.description: Central California is home to the nation's biggest agricultural economy. And farmers there worry that the fear of immigration raids could lead to labor shortages.

item.title: New survey finds many young men in the U.S. are worried about their futures
item.description: A new survey of 1,000 young men in the U.S. shows many feel worried about their futures. NPR speaks with Aaron Smith of the Young Men Research Initiative about the survey and its findings.

item.title: The latest on the escalating conflict between Iran and Israel
item.description: NPR reports the latest on the escalating conflict between Iran and Israel.

item.title: Military analyst discusses possible U.S. objectives if it enters Iran-Israel conflict
item.description: NPR speaks with military analyst Michael Knights, a fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, about possible U.S. objectives if the U.S. enters the Iran-Israel conflict.
